title: Niki Lauda admits Nico Rosberg's Formula One title chance is almost gone
text:
Niki Lauda admits Nico Rosberg's Formula One title chance is almost gone 12 Oct 2015 13:16:53 
comments 
Lewis Hamilton will have to 'retire now and go home' for Nico Rosberg to win this year's Formula One title, according to Mercedes boss Niki Lauda. 
Rosberg has been cast 73 points adrift of Hamilton with only four races remaining after he retired from the lead of Sunday's Russian Grand Prix. 
Hamilton sauntered to his ninth victory of the campaign to edge ever closer to his third championship. 
If the Briton wins in Austin in a fortnight's time and Sebastian Vettel, now his nearest challenger, finishes third or lower, the title will be his. 
Rosberg will be eliminated from the championship battle if Hamilton outscores him by two points. 
Asked about the German's chances after his retirement on lap seven of Sunday's race at Sochi's Olympic Park, Lauda said: "Mathematically yes, but then Lewis has to retire now and go home. He will not. 
"He could have won the race, so if you lose 25 points then it is difficult. 
"He is very disappointed, but he is a racing driver and knows these things can happen, but he will keep on fighting. He fought here very well, he took pole position and led the race. He could have won the race and unfortunately the points are gone. 
"So a racing driver never gives up, Nico especially. He will try in Austin again to do the same thing and hopefully finish in the lead." 
Rosberg, who has now failed to finish two of the last four grands prix through no fault of his own, rued a season he claimed had been blighted by bad luck. 
But Lauda added: "There is generally speaking no good luck and bad luck from my point of view. Nevertheless, our reliability performance in the second half of the season went down. So we have to try and fix that." 
Mercedes belatedly sealed consecutive team titles on Sunday after Ferrari's Kimi Raikkonen was demoted to eighth by the stewards following his last-lap collision with Valtteri Bottas. 
Both Hamilton and Rosberg will head to the team's HQ in Brackley on Monday to celebrate their constructors' championship. Lauda will be in Berlin on a prior commitment, but he recorded a video message ahead of Sunday's race which will be played out to the team's staff. 
On Monday morning, Mercedes tweeted: "Hand shakes, high fives and fist bumps all round right now. Brackley is absolutely buzzing this morning. What a feeling." Related Sport News
